title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not provide both the correct choice and a valid justification equivalent to the following.

· 555 nm MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3EA6@ . Photons with a wavelength of 555 nm MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3EA6@ have a lower frequency than those with a wavelength of 435 nm MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3EA3@ because frequency and wavelength are inversely proportional (ν= c λ ) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3FBD@ . Since frequency and energy are directly proportional (E=h ν) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4053@ , the higher frequency (shorter wavelength) photons have the greater energy.

The response provides both the correct choice and a valid justification equivalent to the following.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not provide both the correct choice and a valid justification equivalent to the following.

· Exothermic. The diagram shows that the absorbance, and therefore the concentration, of HPR + MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3C7D@ is greater at high temperature. The increased concentration of reactants at elevated temperature is consistent with an exothermic reaction, according to Le Châtelier’s principle.

The response provides both the correct choice and a valid justification equivalent to the following.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not correctly explain why the procedure is important for an accurate measurement.

· According to Beer’s law, absorbance and the path length of the cuvette are directly proportional. Thus, identical samples will have different absorbance values if the path length of the cuvette is not the same. Keeping the cuvette path length constant in every experiment ensures that differences in absorbance readings arise only from differences in sample concentration.

The response correctly explains why the procedure is important for an accurate measurement.

· According to Beer’s law, absorbance and the path length of the cuvette are directly proportional. Thus, identical samples will have different absorbance values if the path length of the cuvette is not the same. Keeping the cuvette path length constant in every experiment ensures that differences in absorbance readings arise only from differences in sample concentration.

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not provide a valid explanation equivalent to the following.

· When the concentration of OCl − MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3C9B@ increases, the collisions between reactant particles occur more frequently per unit of time. The greater frequency of collisions leads to an increased rate of product formation and correspondingly a shorter half-life of the reaction.

The response provides a valid explanation equivalent to the following.

· When the concentration of OCl − MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3C9B@ increases, the collisions between reactant particles occur more frequently per unit of time. The greater frequency of collisions leads to an increased rate of product formation and correspondingly a shorter half-life of the reaction.

title: Part I
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not provide both the correct choice and a valid justification equivalent to one of the following.

· The magnitude of Δ H rxn ∘ MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbtv2zVvgiqjxAUrharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeGaeaaakeaacaqGuoGaamisam aaDaaaleaacaWGYbGaamiEaiaad6gaaeaacqWIyiYBaaaaaa@3F31@ will remain the same. Δ H rxn ∘ MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbtv2zVvgiqjxAUrharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeGaeaaakeaacaqGuoGaamisam aaDaaaleaacaWGYbGaamiEaiaad6gaaeaacqWIyiYBaaaaaa@3F31@ is an intensive property, depending on both the enthalpy change and the number of moles reacted. Regardless of the number of moles that react, the ratio of the enthalpy change per mole will always be the same.

OR

· The magnitude of Δ H rxn ∘ MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbtv2zVvgiqjxAUrharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeGaeaaakeaacaqGuoGaamisam aaDaaaleaacaWGYbGaamiEaiaad6gaaeaacqWIyiYBaaaaaa@3F31@ will remain the same. Although the [ OCl − ] MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3E66@ is increased, the number of moles of each reactant that is consumed is the same, as OCl − MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3C9C@ is not the limiting reactant. Hence, the magnitude of the enthalpy change per mole would be the same.

The response provides both the correct choice and a valid justification equivalent to one of the following.

descriptions:
The response does not provide both the correct choice and a valid justification equivalent to the following.

· The concentration of the KOCl MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbtv2zVvgiqjxAUrharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeGaeaaakeaacaqGlbGaae4taiaaboeacaqGSbaaaa@3C50@ solution will be equal to 2.00  M MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3FD1@ .
